thread.title: City startups join forces to fill prescriptions at your doorstep
thread.title_full: City startups join forces to fill prescriptions at your doorstep

author: Jonathan LaMantia
title: City startups join forces to fill prescriptions at your doorstep
text:
August 31, 2015 Updated 08/31/2015 City startups join forces to fill prescriptions at your doorstep On-demand doctor service Pager is partnering with medicine-delivery firm Zipdrug. × On-demand doctor service Pager and medication delivery providers Zipdrug have joined forces 
There has been no shortage of New York City startups looking to disrupt the health care industry, but now two companies are pairing up in that mission. 
Pager , a doctor-on-demand service, has agreed to work with Zipdrug , which allows customers to have prescription medications delivered to their homes or offices. 
Pager's board-certified doctors will offer patients the option of filling their prescriptions through Zipdrug, whose messengers will deliver the medicine, typically within an hour. Pager customers, who pay about $200 per visit and $25 for a phone consultation, will have the delivery fee included in their visit charge. 
Zipdrug users place pharmacy orders on their phones and can track a Zipdrug messenger's trip until their medication arrives. The company charges for the cost of medication, plus a $10 fee, and delivers to most areas of Manhattan. The first delivery is free. 
Its messengers can't deliver prescriptions that qualify as controlled substances, and a patient's physician must electronically submit the order to the pharmacy, said Stu Libby, Zipdrug's chief executive and co-founder. 
Although the company has plenty of competition from pharmacies that deliver, as well as large mail-order services—such as Express Scripts, CVS Caremark and UnitedHealth Group's OptumRx—Mr. Libby believes the service offers superior convenience when a person needs an order filled quickly and doesn't want to venture out to the corner drugstore. 
"We're not trying to introduce a new service," he said. "A lot of pharmacies do deliver. We're just trying to make it easier. I like to equate it to ordering a car service before Uber versus ordering a car service with Uber." 
Pager raised $14 million in Series A funding from investors including Maryland-based New Enterprise Associates and Ashton Kutcher's Sound Ventures in July to expand to San Francisco. It plans to bring Zipdrug's on-demand prescription delivery service with it to California as it ramps up its business in that market in September. 
The company also said Monday it has introduced an app for the Apple Watch that will dispatch a doctor with a single button tap. 
"For us, the partnership with Zipdrug is a natural extension of our on-demand approach," said Andrew Chomer, Pager's vice president of marketing. 
Landing an agreement with a service like Pager is important for Zipdrug as it seeks exposure and growth. The company, which was founded earlier this year, has partnered with "dozens" of medical practices to introduce itself to new patients, Mr. Libby said. 
One such partner is Dr. Matthew Schulman, an Upper East Side plastic surgeon who started working with Zipdrug in July. He said he often prescribes two to three drugs for each surgerym and he feels the company's service gives his practice an edge. 
"My practice is high-end," he said. "I have a patient base that I thought would embrace the technology, and I'm always looking for things that can make patients' experience with me better. As of now, I'm thrilled to be the only plastic surgeon in Manhattan who has access to Zipdrug." 
Mr. Libby declined to disclose how many people had used the service and how many prescriptions it had filled thus far. He said he hopes the service can demonstrate that patients are more likely to take their prescribed medicine when using Zipdrug, preventing costly hospital visits. 
"If we can prove that same-day delivery of prescription medications can reduce the cost of care on a population, then we're really winning," Mr. Libby said. "That's really the goal here."
